question_title: Will North Korea conduct a nuclear test before May 1, 2026?
summary: North Korea has not conducted a nuclear test since September 2017 — over 8 years ago. While Tunnel No. 3 at Punggye-ri has been ready since ~2020, November 2025 satellite imagery shows no signs of imminent test preparations (no instruments, power lines, or cables). The diplomatic environment further suppresses testing likelihood: Trump has dropped denuclearization as a stated goal and signals willingness for engagement with Kim Jong Un, creating a disincentive for provocative nuclear testing. Kim is focused on missile production and testing, not nuclear detonations. The 3-month window is short, and North Korea has repeatedly been assessed as "ready" for years without testing. Applying "Nothing Ever Happens" calibration to the raw base rate (~2.7%/month) and accounting for the restraint pattern and diplomatic context yields a low probability.

factors.description: No satellite evidence of imminent test preparations at Punggye-ri as of Nov 2025 — no instruments, power lines, or cables detected despite Tunnel No. 3 being physically ready since 2020
Diplomatic window with Trump (who dropped denuclearization goal) creates strong disincentive for provocative nuclear testing — Kim would risk closing diplomatic channel
8+ year gap since last test despite being 'ready' — pattern of restraint despite capability. Predictions of imminent testing have not materialized for years
Kim focused on missile production and testing, party congress to unveil nuclear force plans — signals continued buildup but not necessarily a test
US Intelligence Community assessed NK is 'probably prepared' for a test; Tunnel No. 3 physically ready — capability exists and could be exercised quickly if politically decided
North Korea-Russia partnership provides diplomatic cover and may reduce costs of testing if Kim decides to proceed
Short 3-month window (Jan 29 - May 1, 2026) constrains probability even if base rate per month were moderate
